questions.text: A 30-year-old man on drug therapy with a potent oxidizing agent has a self-limiting episode of hemolysis, back pain, and jaundice. The peripheral blood smear reveals non-spherocytic and normocytic anemia; Heinz's bodies are seen in some of his erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A lowered concentration of reduced glutathione

options.label: D
options.text: A reduction of hydrogen peroxide levels

questions.correct_answer: B. A lowered concentration of reduced glutathione

questions.text: A 20-year-old male comes to the E.N.T department with the complaint of ear discharge fever, bilateral facial nerve paralysis, and bilateral profound hearing loss. The patient has a history of abdominal tuberculosis. On otoscopic, the patient is found to have multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Topic Tubercular Otitis Media
Definition Tubercular otitis media is a rare complication of tuberculosis, where the infection affects the middle ear, including the tympanic membrane and middle ear structures.
Etiology Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis. The infection typically spreads from the lungs (primary tuberculosis) or other organs (miliary tuberculosis) to the middle ear.
Clinical Presentation - Ear discharge (otorrhea), which may be chronic and persistent.
  - Profound hearing loss, which can be bilateral.
  - Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane.
  - Tuberculous facial palsy (bilateral or unilateral facial nerve paralysis).
Diagnosis - Detailed medical history and clinical examination, including otoscopy to visualize the tympanic membrane and ear canal.
  - Audiometry (pure-tone and speech audiometry) to assess hearing loss.
  - Imaging studies like CT scan or MRI to evaluate the middle ear and temporal bone.
  - Tuberculin skin test (Mantoux test) or interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) to detect tuberculosis infection.
  - Culture and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for Mycobacterium tuberculosis from ear discharge if possible.
Treatment - Prompt initiation of anti-tuberculosis therapy based on drug susceptibility testing. Treatment usually includes a combination of several anti-tuberculosis drugs for an extended period (6 to 9 months or more).
  - Management of complications, such as hearing aids for hearing loss and supportive care for facial nerve paralysis.
  - Regular follow-up and monitoring for response to treatment and possible adverse effects of anti-tuberculosis medications.
Prognosis The prognosis depends on the severity of the disease, early diagnosis, and initiation of appropriate treatment.

Topic Tubercular Otitis Media
Definition Tubercular otitis media is a rare complication of tuberculosis, where the infection affects the middle ear, including the tympanic membrane and middle ear structures.
Etiology Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis. The infection typically spreads from the lungs (primary tuberculosis) or other organs (miliary tuberculosis) to the middle ear.
Clinical Presentation - Ear discharge (otorrhea), which may be chronic and persistent.
  - Profound hearing loss, which can be bilateral.
  - Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane.
  - Tuberculous facial palsy (bilateral or unilateral facial nerve paralysis).
Diagnosis - Detailed medical history and clinical examination, including otoscopy to visualize the tympanic membrane and ear canal.
  - Audiometry (pure-tone and speech audiometry) to assess hearing loss.
  - Imaging studies like CT scan or MRI to evaluate the middle ear and temporal bone.
  - Tuberculin skin test (Mantoux test) or interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) to detect tuberculosis infection.
  - Culture and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for Mycobacterium tuberculosis from ear discharge if possible.
Treatment - Prompt initiation of anti-tuberculosis therapy based on drug susceptibility testing. Treatment usually includes a combination of several anti-tuberculosis drugs for an extended period (6 to 9 months or more).
  - Management of complications, such as hearing aids for hearing loss and supportive care for facial nerve paralysis.
  - Regular follow-up and monitoring for response to treatment and possible adverse effects of anti-tuberculosis medications.
Prognosis The prognosis depends on the severity of the disease, early diagnosis, and initiation of appropriate treatment. With prompt and adequate therapy, some patients may experience improvement in symptoms and recovery of hearing. However, in severe cases with extensive damage, permanent hearing loss or other complications may occur.
Prevention Preventing tuberculosis through vaccination (BCG vaccine) and early detection and treatment of tuberculosis cases in the community may help reduce the incidence of tubercular otitis media.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a humerus fracture after a road track accident. The orthopedic surgeon admitted him; he is posted for open reduction and external fixation. As soon as the patient was administered the local anesthetic agent, he exhibited the symptoms of seizures and sensory and visual changes with a reduced level of consciousness . What is the next step in the management of this patient?

A nineteen years old male presents to your clinic with symptoms of a gradually progressive, painless decrease of vision in both eyes. Other medical problems include a recent decrease in hearing and has been having blood in his urine for quite some time now. questions.text: A 47-year-old lady with left calf pain, edema, and erythema, diagnosed with a popliteal vein thrombosis, was prescribed warfarin. questions.text: A low-risk primigravida undergoes vaginal delivery. An episiotomy is performed due to a protracted second stage of labor. Two hours after delivery, the patient appears pale. questions.text: A 53-year-old female is admitted to the post-operative floor after a mastectomy for a large malignant phyllodes tumor. On the 2 nd post-operative day, the output from the suction drain is 80ml for 24 hours . The intern accidentally removed the drain on 3 rd postoperative day. On examination, the patient has oozing serosanguinous fluid from the wound with swelling around the wound . Which of the following can prevent this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Aspiration under aseptic conditions and pressure dressing

questions.explanation:
Surgical Complications and Unwanted Side-effects Key Strategies on Prevention
Flap necrosis Provide an adequate layer of subcutaneous tissue in the flap
Dehiscence Plan incision properly to avoid tension; close and repair wound securely
Seroma Provide adequate drainage
Bleeding and hematoma Ensure effective and adequate hemostasis
Infection Maintain sterility of the operative field
latrogenic injuries Dissect carefully and precisely
Dog ear Plan and close incision properly (with trimming if needed to avoid dog ear)
Ugly scar Plan and close incision properly to promote a cosmetically acceptable scar
Local recurrence Provide adequate surgical margins around the breast cancer mass

The question sought the calculation of net filtration pressure for this patient. What would it be?

A 30-year-old woman was one among the 5 people who had died after being exposed to some poisonous fumes at the factory she was working in. By the time the body was brought for an autopsy, the doctor noticed that there was Chocolate brown hypostasis in the back, over the buttocks, thighs, and posterior side of the arm. This can be secondary to exposure to any one of the following, except?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ PM hypostasis or lividity or PM Staining-Settling down of blood in dependent parts due to gravity. It is used to detect the time since death, the position of the body, and the cause of death. Normal color: Bluish, purplish CO poisoning: Cherry red CN poisoning: Brick red H 2 S poisoning: Bluish green/red Chocolate brown: Potassium chlorate, Aniline and Nitrites.
  • ➤ PM hypostasis or lividity or PM Staining-Settling down of blood in dependent parts due to gravity. It is used to detect the time since death, the position of the body, and the cause of death. Normal color: Bluish, purplish CO poisoning: Cherry red CN poisoning: Brick red H 2 S poisoning: Bluish green/red Chocolate brown: Potassium chlorate, Aniline and Nitrites.
  • ➤ Normal color: Bluish, purplish CO poisoning: Cherry red CN poisoning: Brick red H 2 S poisoning: Bluish green/red Chocolate brown: Potassium chlorate, Aniline and Nitrites.
  • ➤ Normal color: Bluish, purplish
  • ➤ CO poisoning: Cherry red
  • ➤ CN poisoning: Brick red
  • ➤ H 2 S poisoning: Bluish green/red
  • ➤ Chocolate brown: Potassium chlorate, Aniline and Nitrites.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is presented to the physician by his mother with complaints of right foot swelling for three days. He has no history of any other abnormalities. There is no family history of lymphedema. The patient if febrile. On physical examination, the right foot had pitting edema and a positive Stemmer’s sign . A lymphoscintigram was performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following will be the most common bacterial infection that can occur in this patient?

A professor is giving a lecture on plasma osmolality and gives an example of a woman who runs a marathon in 32.2°C (90°F) weather. After the race, she feels exhausted, and thirsty and drinks plenty of distilled water. It replaces all volume lost in sweat. Which of the following statements is true regarding her body's fluid status?

A psychiatrist is being called to the emergency department to assess a 40-year-old woman. The patient has a history of chronic depression. " My belly and chest are empty," she says. "My organs have all died. I'm not here. I'm no longer alive." Which of the following best describes her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Option D: Delusions of reference
  • ↳ Delusions of reference imply that the patient believes that normal events are of special importance to them. The symptoms described in the above case do not suggest any idea of reference, so this option is incorrect.
  • ↳ Delusions of reference imply that the patient believes that normal events are of special importance to them.
  • ↳ The symptoms described in the above case do not suggest any idea of reference, so this option is incorrect.
    • References:

    • ↳ Delusions are fixed or false beliefs maintained despite being contradicted by reality or rational arguments and unrelated to one's religious beliefs or culture.
    • ↳ Delusions are a common symptom of psychotic disorders like schizophrenia.
    • ↳ Nihilistic delusions are fixed, false beliefs about one’s death.
    • ↳ Paranoid delusions are based on the constant and fixed irrational fear that someone or some group will mistreat, harm, and sabotage the affected person.
    • ↳ Delusions of persecution are characterized by suspicion of being cheated on, conspired against, or harassed.
    • ↳ Delusions of reference imply that the patient believes that normal events are of special importance to them.

Isometric ventricular contraction QRS complex Starts with AV valve closure c wave due to bulging of AV valves back to atria 1st

Stage AV valves* Semilunar valves† Status of ventricles and atria; and blood flow
1 Isovolumic relaxation closed closed Semilunar (pulmonary and aortic) valves close at the end of the ejection stage; blood flow stops.
2a Inflow: (Ventricular filling) open closed Ventricles and atria together relax and expand; blood flows to the heart during ventricular and atrial diastole.
2b Inflow: (Ventricular filling with Atrial systole#) open closed Ventricles relaxed and expanded; atrial contraction (systole) forces blood under pressure into ventricles during ventricular diastole.
3 Isovolumic contraction closed closed AV valves close at the end of ventricular diastole; blood flow stops; ventricles begin to contract.
4 Ejection: Ventricular ejection closed open Ventricles contract (ventricular systole); blood flows from the heart—to the lungs and the rest of the body during ventricular ejection.

A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and confusion. On examination, he is found to have weakness in his left arm and leg. A head CT scan reveals a hypodense area in the right cerebral hemisphere. A subsequent MRI shows a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, and histopathological examination shows an area of necrosis with neutrophilic infiltrate. What is the most likely type of necrosis observed in this case?
questions.explanation:
Type of Necrosis Description and Pathogenesis Example
Coagulative Necrosis Tissue architecture is preserved initially, but the cell outlines are lost. The affected tissue becomes eosinophilic due to denaturation of proteins. Commonly seen in ischemic injuries. Myocardial infarction (heart attack)
Liquefactive Necrosis The affected tissue transforms into a fluid-filled space due to the action of hydrolytic enzymes, particularly in the presence of neutrophils. Commonly observed in bacterial or fungal infections and brain infarctions. Brain abscess
Caseous Necrosis Characterized by a "cheese-like" appearance with a combination of cellular debris and amorphous granular material. Commonly seen in granulomatous infections like tuberculosis. Tuberculous granuloma
Fat Necrosis Occurs in adipose tissue after trauma or inflammation. Fatty acids are hydrolyzed, leading to the formation of chalky-white areas. Acute pancreatitis
Fibrinoid Necrosis Typically observed in immune reactions involving blood vessels. Fibrinoid material accumulates in and around damaged vessel walls. Polyarteritis nodosa
Gangrenous Necrosis Refers to large areas of tissue death, often involving multiple tissue layers and frequently seen in extremities. Can be dry or wet, with or without superimposed infection. Dry gangrene in a limb due to arterial blockage, Wet gangrene with bacterial infection in a wound.
Apoptotic (Programmed) Necrosis Also known as apoptosis, it is a tightly regulated form of cell death with distinct morphological features. It plays a role in tissue remodeling and the elimination of damaged or unnecessary cells. Physiological cell turnover, Embryonic development, Immune response.

  • Tocolytics in preterm labour given only in this phase

Phase of Labor Description Duration (Approximate)
Latent Phase (Early Labor) - The initial phase of labor. Variable
  - Cervix starts to efface (thin out) and dilate (open).  
  - Contractions may begin, but they are usually mild and irregular.  
  - The woman may experience backache, cramps, or a show (mucus discharge).  
Active Phase - Cervical dilation progresses more rapidly. 6-12 hours (approx.)
  - Contractions become more intense, frequent, and regular.  
  - Cervix dilates from around 4 cm to 10 cm.  
  - The woman may experience increased discomfort and a strong urge to push.  
Transition Phase - The final phase before the pushing stage. 30 minutes to 2 hours
  - Cervix completes dilation (reaches 10 cm).  
  - Contractions may be very intense and frequent.  
  - The woman may feel exhausted and overwhelmed.  
  - Nausea, shivering, and emotional changes may occur.  
Pushing (Second Stage) - The phase of active pushing to deliver the baby. Variable
  - The woman actively pushes during contractions to help the baby move down the birth canal.  
  - This stage ends with the baby's delivery.  
Placental Delivery (Third Stage) - The delivery of the placenta (afterbirth). Generally within 30 minutes after the baby's birth.
  - Contractions continue to help expel the placenta.

questions.explanation:
CHOLANGITIS
  • Acute cholangitis is due to an acute, ascending bacterial infection of the biliary tree caused by an obstruction.
  • The classic presentation of cholangitis is Charcot triad with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain.
  • Reynolds pentad is Charcot triad + Shock +  Altered mental status (features of shock)
  • Stones are the most common cause of obstruction in cholangitis.
  • The most common pathogens include Klebsiella, E.coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species

Diagnosis:

  • Leukocytosis with an abnormal liver panel is common.
  • Ultrasound should be the first screening test and will commonly show dilation of the biliary tree.
  • ERCP is critical not only to identify and localize the obstruction but also to drain the biliary tree and obtain culture and biopsy specimens of a lesion if necessary

Treatment:

  • Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics
  • Urgent stone removal by ERCP if the patient does not respond to medical therapy and will progress to shock
  • Patients who have suffered an episode of acute cholangitis related to gallstone disease should be recommended to undergo elective cholecystectomy approximately 6 weeks after the resolution of cholangitis

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain upon exertion for one week. The heated argument had turned violent and ended with the other person shooting at the victim with his unlicensed rifle. To avoid being exposed, that person and the bar owner had taken the victim to a doctor who had accepted to remove the bullet and suture the wound in private. The victim had unfortunately succumbed to the injuries in the early hours of this morning. While performing the autopsy, the forensic doctor faced difficulty in determining the entry and exit of the bullet wound. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ The evaluation of whether the wound was an entrance or an exit becomes difficult due to surgical alteration. It is in reference to the late US President John F Kennedy who was shot and during the autopsy, the doctor directly opened the entry wound to remove the bullet.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was examined by the team doctor after he sustained an injury to his knees and shin during an ongoing cricket match. He had attempted a difficult fielding where he had instinctively dived and skidded on his knees for a short distance on the rough unkempt school playground. Examination of his legs revealed multiple parallel and longitudinal scratches that had some avulsed skin gathered at the edge of the wound near the apex of the patella. The doctor identified them to be graze wounds which is a type of?
questions.explanation:
Scratch
  • Caused by a sharp, pointed object.
  • Surface layers of skin are heaped up in the direction of movement, so epithelial tags can be seen at the end. Eg., fingernails, pins or thorns.
Graze or Brush burn or gravel rash
  • Most common type.
  • A collection of innumerable scratch abrasions. Due to violent rubbing of skin on a rough surface ( eg. dragging over the road).
  • Comprise uneven, longitudinal parallel lines with epithelium heaped up at the end of these lines. This heap-up indicates the direction of the force. eg., roadside accident, glancing kick,
Pressure
  • Caused when a relatively less amount of force is applied for a relatively long time.
  • Corneal abrasions due to contact lens, ligature mark in hanging, shoe bite, teeth bitemark, nappy abrasions
Impact
  • Caused when a relatively large amount of force is applied for a relatively short period.
  • Slightly depressed below the surface
  • The dermis is damaged - underlying bruise. eg., Headlamp rim marks in a head-on collision, recoil/muzzle impression in contact gunshot injury, Tire marks of a car, bus, or truck in run-over accidents
Patterned
  • The pattern of the object causing reproduced on the skin. Eg., bicycle chain.

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Treatment of Carbon Monoxide:
  • ➤ Treatment of Carbon Monoxide:
  • ➤ Remove the victim from the source of exposure. Maintain patent airway, fresh air, and orthobaric oxygen (high-flow or 100% oxygen at atmospheric pressure) Oxygen therapy is started if COHb > 10% and should be given for 4–6 hours. Blood transfusion, if required. Gastric lavage to prevent Aspiration Pneumonia. Cerebral edema is treated by Mannitol. Extra: Tests that may be used for the diagnosis of CO poisoning: Spectroscopy Hoppe-Seyler's test Kunkel's test Potassium ferricyanide test Katayama's test

A 50-year-old patient with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents to the emergency department with a severe headache for the last hour. On physical examination, blood pressure is 210/120 mm Hg, the pulse is 106/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. On a CT scan, the doctor finds a hyperintense region in the temporal lobe and the affected area is labeled in the image below: The damage to this area can result in which one of the following?

options.label: D
options.text: Failure of comprehension of spoken or written words

questions.correct_answer: D. Failure of comprehension of spoken or written words
questions.explanation:
Aspect Broca's Area Wernicke's Area
Location Frontal lobe, typically in the left hemisphere. Temporal lobe, usually in the left hemisphere.
Function Language production and speech motor control. Language comprehension and semantic processing.
Role in Language Critical for forming grammatically correct sentences. Critical for understanding spoken and written language.
Broca's Aphasia Lesions here can lead to Broca's aphasia, characterized by difficulty in forming coherent sentences, speech production deficits. Lesions here can lead to Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech, impaired comprehension.
Fluency Reduced fluency, speech may be slow and effortful. Speech is fluent but may lack meaningful content.
Grammar and Syntax Impaired grammar and syntax in speech. Grammar and syntax remain intact, although speech may not make sense.
Comprehension Generally, comprehension of spoken language is intact. Comprehension of language is impaired, speech may not be understood.
Motor Control Involved in the control of speech muscles. Not directly involved in motor control.
Association Connected to Wernicke's area via the arcuate fasciculus. Connected to Broca's area via the arcuate fasciculus.
Neighboring Regions Adjacent to the precentral gyrus (motor cortex). Adjacent to the auditory cortex.

During the treatment of septic shock, a 28-year-old male remains hypotensive despite adequate volume replacement. When dopamine is started, ventricular tachycardia develops, and this is unresponsive to lidocaine. The V-tach converts back to sinus rhythm once the dopamine is stopped. At this point, which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this hypotensive patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Severe and life-threatening condition resulting from an infection that leads to systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and organ dysfunction.
Causes Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections. Common sources include lungs (pneumonia), abdomen (peritonitis), and bloodstream (bacteremia).
Pathophysiology Infection triggers an overwhelming immune response, releasing inflammatory mediators causing widespread endothelial damage, tissue hypoperfusion, and multi-organ dysfunction.
Clinical Signs - High fever or hypothermia- Rapid heart rate- Hypotension- Altered mental status- Labored breathing- Organ failure
Diagnosis - Clinical assessment- Blood cultures- Lab tests (e.g., complete blood count, lactate levels)- Imaging (to identify infection source)
Criteria for Sepsis - Infection suspected or confirmed- Two or more SIRS criteria (e.g., abnormal temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, white blood cell count)
Criteria for Septic Shock Sepsis with persistent hypotension despite adequate fluid resuscitation along with signs of organ dysfunction.
Treatment - Immediate administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics- Source control (draining abscesses, removing infected tissue)- Fluid resuscitation- Vasopressors to maintain blood pressure
Supportive Care - Oxygen therapy- Mechanical ventilation if needed- Renal replacement therapy for kidney failure- Nutritional support
Prognosis High mortality rate, but early recognition and prompt treatment improve outcomes.
Complications - Multiple organ failure- Long-term physical and psychological effects
Prevention - Proper wound care and hygiene- Vaccinations- Early detection and management of infections
